review.title: Tackling Dynamic Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows by means of Ant Colony System
review.abstract: The Dynamic Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows (DVRPTW) is an extension of the well-known Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP), which takes into account the dynamic nature of the problem. This aspect requires the vehicle routes to be updated in an ongoing manner as new customer requests arrive in the system and must be incorporated into an evolving schedule during the working day. Besides the vehicle capacity constraint involved in the classical VRP, DVRPTW considers in addition time windows, which are able to better capture real-world situations. Despite this, so far, few studies have focused on tackling this problem of greater practical importance. To this end, this study devises for the resolution of DVRPTW, an ant colony optimization based algorithm, which resorts to a joint solution construction mechanism, able to construct in parallel the vehicle routes. This method is coupled with a local search procedure, aimed to further improve the solutions built by ants, and with an insertion heuristics, which tries to reduce the number of vehicles used to service the available customers. The experiments indicate that the proposed algorithm is competitive and effective, and on DVRPTW instances with a higher dynamicity level, it is able to yield better results compared to existing ant-based approaches.
authors: madalina raschip faculty of computer science

metadata.title: Tackling Dynamic Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows by means of Ant Colony System

sections.heading: II. THE VEHICLE ROUTING PROBLEM WITH TIME WINDOWS
sections.text: In this section we describe the (static) vehicle routing problem with time windows (VRPTW), which is the static variant of our mentioned DVRPTW problem. As in the classical VRP or the capacity VRP, VRPTW has to find a number of routes for each vehicle, so that each customer who has a specific demand is visited by a single vehicle exactly once and the total demand at the Route2017 IEEEEEP Congress (CEC) PREPRINT; the camera-free version is published in IEEE procedures.

sections.heading: III. RELATED WORK
sections.text: In recent decades, the VRP and its famous VRPTW extension has been transformed into an intensive field of research. Heuristic and precise optimization approaches have been developed for the VRPTW problem. Surveys of the proposed techniques can be conducted in two colonies, in which the number of vehicles is optimized and the total time of the vehicles is optimized. They have been proposed for the VRPTW problem.

sections.heading: IV. THE ANT COLONY SYSTEM
sections.text: Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) is a nature-inspired metaheuristics that follows the metaphor of real ants that manage to find the shortest paths between their nest and food sources. In the case of ACO, each artificial ant, henceforth referred to as an "ant," constructs solutions in a probable manner by adding iterative components until a complete solution to the problem is found. In constructing a solution, an ant is influenced by two factors: 1) pheromone pathways that are dynamically updated during runtime and reflect the ant's acquired search experience, and 2) heuristic information, which is a static value, depending on the problem. The algorithm presented in this study is based on the ant colony system (ACS) [17], which is a successor to the ant system (AS) [18]. AS is the first ACO algorithm to be proposed in the literature, and the following solution for the PRP was originally developed by the PRP.

sections.heading: V. THE ALGORITHM INVESTIGATED FOR DVRPTW
sections.text: This section describes our approach to the DVRPTW problem, which is based on the metaheuristic approach of the ant colony system outlined in Section IV. To address the dynamics of the problem, we have adopted in our algorithm the time intersection and node connection approach of the MACSDVRPTW ant Solver introduced in [14]. Accordingly, a working day of twd seconds is divided equally into nts time intersections, calculating the length of one time intersection (tts) as: tts = twd / nts. Thus, the initial DVRPTW problem is divided into nts static problems, which are solved one after the other. In this context, we introduce the concept of the current problem configuration, which designates one of these static problems, defined by the subset of available nodes (customer requirements). We will use Sbest to designate the currently optimal solution, which is the best workable solution, each of which is the previously known problem being merged, each of which is referred to as the next part of the problem.

sections.heading: A. The planner
sections.text: Prior to the start of the working day, an initial workable solution (in terms of capacity, window and arrival time of the vehicle at the depot) is defined, which is built with the time-based nearest heuristic execution introduced in [19]. The time-based nearest neighbor heuristic is a sequential tour building algorithm that takes into account both the geographical and temporal proximity of the customers. This initial solution defines the preliminary tours for the vehicles, taking into account only one priori node known in the system from the outset. First, a vehicle starts its tour from the depot, then iteratively adds the next (in terms of a metric m) unvisited customer, which is guided relative to the last customer on that tour, while remaining feasible. The metric mij, which defines the proximity between i, the last customer on the current emerging tour, and j, the speakers report to each unrouted customer.

sections.heading: VI. EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Problem instances
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point where there is only one person who is able to decide whether he will be able to take care of another person or whether he will be able to find another person who is able to be another person.

sections.heading: B. Parameters setup
sections.text: In order to allow a fair comparison of the two examined algorithms DVRPTW-ACS and MACS-DVRPTW, we used the same setting of the parameters whose values we took from [14]. For the ACS-based algorithms, we set: q0 = 0.9, α = 1.0, β = 1.0 and the number of ants was set to 10, while we set for the dynamic scenario: twd = 100 seconds and nts = 50. In addition, we applied the pheromone conservation strategy in both algorithms by specifying ρ = 0.3 in the equation: τij = (1 − ρ) · forth old ij + ρ · τ0. In addition, the size of the candidate list used in our algorithm was set to cl = 20. For both algorithms, 30 runs were performed on a Linux server with 6 GB of RAM memory, processor Intel Core 2 Duo P9xxx (Penryn Class C2) at 2.5 GHz.

sections.heading: C. Results
sections.text: This year, it is at an all-time high in the history of the European Union.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: This year, the number of new arrivals has increased by 0.7 percent compared to the previous year.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
sections.text: We thank the authors of the MACS-DVRPTW Solver [14] for providing their source code, which enabled us to perform the comparison with our algorithm, which is partially funded by the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under Funding Agreement No 692178.

referenceMentions.context: In this paper, we considered that the dynamic nature of DVRP is given by the customers requests, which is the most common source of dynamism, as pointed out in [2].

By its description, it can be noticed that VRPTW is more complicated than multiple traveling salesman problem (mTSP), problem that we have tackled in our previous studies [3], [4] with ant colony based methods, and for which we proposed a benchmark.

By its description, it can be noticed that VRPTW is more complicated than multiple traveling salesman problem (mTSP), problem that we have tackled in our previous studies [3], [4] with ant colony based methods, and for which we proposed a benchmark.
Surveys of proposed techniques can be found in [5], [6].
Surveys of proposed techniques can be found in [5], [6].
A multi-ant colony system consisting in two colonies, one for optimizing the number of vehicles and one for optimizing the total travel time, was proposed for the VRPTW problem in [7].
A comprehensive review of applications and approaches for dynamic vehicle routing problems is given in [2].
A taxonomy of papers concerning DVRP problems was developed in [8].
Also, the interested reader is referred to [9], for a survey of hybrid artificial intelligence algorithms, employed for solving DVRP problems.
A first such study is due to [10], which presents a tabu search algorithm that works on the DVRPTW, but with soft time windows.

A hybrid genetic approach based on two populations of individuals which evolve concurrently are used to minimize the total traveled distance, and respectively, the number of unserviced customers, total lateness at customers locations and temporal constraint violations in [11].
In [13], the DVRPTW problem is decomposed into several static VRPTW problems, which are then solved using an improved large neighborhood search algorithm.
To the best of our knowledge, the study from [14] is the only ant colony based approach found in the literature, that tackles the DVRPTW problem.
To this end, the authors propose an ACO based method, denoted as MACS-DVRPTW, by extending to the dynamical case the state-of-the-art ant algorithm [7] developed for VRPTW.
This study was continued in [15], where MACS-DVRPTW was applied to schedule the routes of a fleet of cars for a surveillance company.
Recently, MACSDVRPTW was enhanced in [16] with two strategies for dealing with DVRPTW problem in which customers have different priority levels.
The algorithm presented in this study is based on the Ant Colony System (ACS) [17], which is a successor of the Ant System (AS) [18].
The algorithm presented in this study is based on the Ant Colony System (ACS) [17], which is a successor of the Ant System (AS) [18].
To tackle the dynamic nature of the problem, we adopted in our algorithm the time slices and nodes commitment approach from the MACSDVRPTW ant based solver, introduced in [14].

Before the beginning of the working day, an initial feasible solution (with respect to capacity, time window and vehicle arrival time at the depot constraints), is built using the timeoriented nearest neighbour heuristic, introduced in [19].

After committing the necessary nodes from the tours of S, if condition 1) holds, the list of available customer requests is updated and the new available nodes are added in the tours of S by adopting the insertion technique from I1 insertion heuristic [19].
In the implementation of the algorithm, we resorted to candidate lists, as indicated in [20], when solving instances of TSP with ACS.

where ρ ∈ (0, 1) is a local pheromone decay parameter and for the ∆τrs we have used the following setting, as indicated in [17]: ∆τrs = τ0, where τ0 is the initial pheromone level, computed as in equation (2).
This method consists of two multi-route operators, relocate and exchange [21], which modify simultaneously two different tours.
The experimental analysis in this paper is conducted on several DVRPTW instances, belonging to the benchmark introduced in [14].
To allow a fair comparison of the two investigated algorithms, DVRPTW-ACS andMACS-DVRPTW, we used the same setting of the parameters, their values being taken from [14].
To assess the performance of the proposed algorithm, we compared it with another ACO based approach from the literature, namely MACS-DVRPTW, described in [14].
3 wpp, no IIS” in [14], since according to the results the authors reported in their study, this variant achieves overall one of the best results on DVRPTW instances with 50% dynamicity.
We would like to thank to the authors of MACS-DVRPTW solver [14] for providing us their source code, that allowed us to perform the comparison with our algorithm.

metadata.abstractText: The Dynamic Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows (DVRPTW) is an extension of the well-known Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP), which takes into account the dynamic nature of the problem. This aspect requires the vehicle routes to be updated in an ongoing manner as new customer requests arrive in the system and must be incorporated into an evolving schedule during the working day. Besides the vehicle capacity constraint involved in the classical VRP, DVRPTW considers in addition time windows, which are able to better capture realworld situations. Despite this, so far, few studies have focused on tackling this problem of greater practical importance. To this end, this study devises for the resolution of DVRPTW, an ant colony optimization based algorithm, which resorts to a joint solution construction mechanism, able to construct in parallel the vehicle routes. This method is coupled with a local search procedure, aimed to further improve the solutions built by ants, and with an insertion heuristics, which tries to reduce the number of vehicles used to service the available customers. The experiments indicate that the proposed algorithm is competitive and effective, and on DVRPTW instances with a higher dynamicity level, it is able to yield better results compared to existing ant-based approaches.
